The more media attention an issue has the more partisan and less productive the Congressional hearing will be.

A gauge of the purpose of the hearing is whether or not the Congressmen ask real or rhetorical questions of witnesses. Sadly, in most hearings, the questions are rhetorical.

Contrast the recent hearing about the London Whale fiasco conducted by Senators Levin and McCain with just about any hearing called by Rep. Issa to see what bona fide hearings look like.

Dear Dr. K and Conmenters,

I urge you to watch the Peterson Forum. This is the link, in case you missed it. http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/DebtandTa

I am interested if any of you can see a potential compromise between what Senator Murray is saying and what Representative Ryan is saying.. Believe it or not I see a possible agreement that will achieve what both are calling for. The recommended Great Compromise is based on the broad economic, wellness interests of American families from all income levels.

These are short term emergency measures to put people back to work & address the anemic economic recovery. We can move toward a more deliberative long term fix to address our long term debt liabilities built this emergency measure. The big goal is to be fair in tax & spending policy to broadly share US prosperity.
1) Repeal the sequester
2) Restore the payroll tax cut
3) Eliminate cap on payroll FICA tax.
4) Increase Minimum Wage to the dollar number that takes 40 hour a week workers off SNAP and Welfare Assistance. I think the number is $18 per hour but I defer tonight to anyone's calculation that saves food stamps, etc.
5) Repeal Obamacare and enlarge Medicare to include all including VA, Tricare, Civil Service, etc. Expand Medicare to include dental and eyecare.
6) Allow Medicare to negotiate for drug prices.
6) Tax ALL individual Income at same rate
7) Reduce Corporate tax rate to 10% and eliminate all preferences that benefit only a few

Pogo is right, let's bring back the rules that allowed her/his ancestors to come in. As people arrive, unannounced, we check them for a couple of diseases, that they are not criminals, and that they have someone local that will vouch for them.  If the same rules applied today, then we could finally have enough legal workers to carry out their own path to happiness for their grandchildren. While I am sure that these laudable efforts at high school level  help some lower SE students get into college, I feel that efforts are more urgently needed in the elementary grades. In the poor school district where I used to teach, the facilities and staff were abysmal, completely inadequate to help underprivileged kids -- a majority of students in lunch programs, with one parent at home etc. Compared with the one that my grandson attends -- large PTA help with efforts and funds, field trips, art & music, reading tutors etc., all complementing parental involvement -- the former are at a disadvantage long before high school.

If employers can get immigrants in because "Americans won't take these jobs" we'll soon see more and more jobs lose wages and benefits, as construction jobs have over the past couple of decades, until finally the conditions will be bad and wages so low that even the immigrants already here won't take the jobs.

Puzzled, I'm puzzled.
My point is that Affirmative Action in its purest and most excellent form succeeded in doing our nation's greatest haters the service of propagating a value system that takes into account race in and of itself as, well, something of value.

Programs that stray from true Affirmative Action threaten to teach our youth that what matters is their intellect, drive, potential and culture, rather than the beautiful chocolate or creamy custard that covers their bones, muscles, and adipose tissue.

Programs that are billed as targeting particular economic groups, or particular neighborhoods will hopefully be a more politically palatable way of ensuring that veritable rainbow full of colorful people are admitted to our nation's great institutions. Once these programs begin working, however, and race becomes dissociated from such factors as economic status, the program will be in a crisis.

I disagree. And here's why... How do you compare a disadvantaged kid who scores 1100 on the SAT, has gone to a less challenging high school and helped to support his family vs. an advantaged student whose parents provided every opportunity in life, has rarely worked, had expensive SAT test prep and scores 1200 on the SAT? By your simplistic standards, the disadvantaged kid is not as "deserving" of college admission? Bull.

It is absolutely part of the responsibility of universities to encourage talented students from a variety of backgrounds to attend college. It actually how you reduce inequality, rather than solidifying it.
In America, at least in 2013, the author is correct. Our political spectrum is a disgrace... sixty years ago, Obama would probably have been considered a moderate Republican!

Jorge, you can cut that number in half.

Obama would have fit in perfectly with moderate Republicans 30 years ago as well.

"Centrist Republicans like Rove ..."

I don't think centrist means what the author thinks it means.

I think you overstate the GOP's woes. It may be on its way to being a regional party, but it nevertheless controls the House and paralyzes the Senate -- and that *after* an election that was moderately successful for Democrats.

The fearful, the uninformed, the greedy, and the resentful remain powerful constituencies because they are far more motivated to vote than the bulk of the population -- and all these groups are in the GOP's pocket.

Ah, much gnashing of teeth and rending of garments. Why? Because there is no way out for the GOP.

To avoid a generation as a regional party, it must transform its platform, but to move toward the hispanics and women that it needs is to move directly away from the social conservatives that it also needs. To make up for that loss, the GOP will need to get LOTS of new voters, and the only way to do that is to have a platform that will attract them in droves; in other words, become Democrats.

So, the only way to save the party is to destroy it.

Andrew, this is exactly the reaction of many white guys that bother me. You have a bad experience with one person of a certain type and, all of a sudden, you paint everyone else with the same stereotype.

I, too, am white. I, too, was forced to work with an unholy terror that happened to be an African-American female even worse than the one you met. (I left when she threatened harm to myself and a co-worker.) However, I have worked with far more really nice middle-class people who happened to be African-American and I'm not going to dismiss everyone just because of one horrific experience.

Dear Reader in Wash,

No, women are routinely discriminated against. I'm female. I've worked consistently for 20 years. In my last job, men who had no or some college were making more to start than I was with my Master's-level education. My female co-workers also got paid less than newly-hired males with less education and experience. Complain and you get forced out. One of my female co-workers who complained was literally told to go back to her desk and she would be given no work until she quit. (Firing people meant they might have to pay unemployment, you see.)

My former employer and their parent company had discrimination cases going back a decade--because the owners truly believe that white men make better employees.

Oh, and I did get "maternity leave" of six weeks--unpaid. And that I had to shorten to three as they issued veiled threats that they would fire me if I stayed out even that long.

By the way, the men there that were promoted over me had not only less education, but some also were there LESS time than I was.
